prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not changing the movie that I chose for my birthday.
so this happened a while ago and I'm curious if I was the asshole.

It was just before my 20th birthday and I decided I wanted to see a movie as my birthday party/gift to myself, I discovered that How to Train Your Dragon 3 was out so I thought id go see it. 

I posted on the group chat the date and time of the movie and asked if anybody wanted to join me for a birthday movie. I said its completely optional if you want to join me. 

most of the group agreed and I was happy. 
That was until one of them said why don't we pick a different movie, I replied saying that it was my birthday and it's the movie I picked, we could see another movie on another day if you want, but I really want to see How to Train Your Dragon. 

After realising they wouldn't change my mind they told me they weren't coming and stopped talking in the group chat. 

I'm now unsure if I should have changed the movie or not.

AITA?

and just incase anyone asks, I like how to train your dragon because it's a good movie. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who didn't change the movie for their birthday is in the wrong. The situation is that they wanted to see How to Train Your Dragon 3 for their 20th birthday and invited friends. Initially, most agreed, but then one person suggested a different movie. The author refused, saying it's their birthday and they wanted that movie. The person then backed out and stopped talking. Now the author is unsure if they should have changed it.

First, the author made it clear the movie was optional. They invited people but didn't pressure anyone. When someone objected, the author stood by their choice, which is their right since it's their birthday. The friend who left could have chosen not to go but instead decided to withdraw from the group, which might be their issue. The author didn't force anyone to attend; they just wanted to see the movie they chose. The friend's reaction seems harsh, especially since the author was upfront about it being their choice. So, the answer would be B, the author isn't in the wrong. They had the right to pick their movie for their own birthday celebration.
